user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_mkconsistent_:
```c
static int lfs_fs_mkconsistent_(lfs_t *lfs) {
    // lfs_fs_forceconsistency does most of the work here
    int err = lfs_fs_forceconsistency(lfs);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // do we have any pending gstate?
    lfs_gstate_t delta = {0};
    lfs_gstate_xor(&delta, &lfs->gdisk);
    lfs_gstate_xor(&delta, &lfs->gstate);
    if (!lfs_gstate_iszero(&delta)) {
        // lfs_dir_commit will implicitly write out any pending gstate
        lfs_mdir_t root;
        err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &root, NULL, 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Cannot determine from this single call whether Rule 8.13 is violated. The call itself (err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);) does not show a pointer declaration lacking const. A violation would occur if lfs_dir_fetch’s third parameter is declared as a pointer to a non-const type (e.g. type *p) but the function does not modify the pointed-to object — in that case the parameter should be declared as a pointer to const (e.g. const type *p). To decide definitively, inspect the prototype of lfs_dir_fetch and the type of lfs->root; if the function does not modify the data and the parameter is non-const, change the parameter to a pointer-to-const.
